author: LAPhill
content:
By far, the most important element in realistic orchestral sound is in the programming. You need a controller where you can automate cc1 and cc11 (modulation and expression). Instruments, especially strings, are constantly changing their volumes. Particularly on entrances and phrase-ends. If you don't have a controller for this, you can draw it all in, but that gets really tedious.

If you get that figured out, I can almost guarantee that just about any library out there will get you good results. So then it's just a matter of what sound do you gravitate towards, how elaborate of a feature set do you need, etc. Legatos are overrated and I'd take no legato over a poorly programmed one any day.

If you want a full orchestra, not just strings, I'd check out some of the all-in-one offerings from Spitfire (Albion, BBC Orchestra, or Abbey Road), East West, Orchestral Tools (Inspire), or VSL (Prime). They all will have several different articulations, a decent amount of dynamic layers, and a full set of orchestral instruments. Have a listen to them and see what sounds grab you. Spitfire and Orchestral Tools have a more prominent room sound baked in, but they all do to some extent. So be aware that, whichever library you choose, there's a certain amount of "reverb" (which is actually just the hall they're recorded in) that you will never be able to turn off.

author: Slow Hand
content:
One tip I'd give is to make your patch while you have a MIDI sequence playing. Not just some static, even arpeggio that you drew in, but a part that has different articulations, note lengths, velocities, and covers a range of notes.

It's easy when making a patch to just keep your finger on one key and go *doot doot doot* (tweak) *doot doot doot* (tweak again). What you can end up doing this way is optimizing the patch and parameters for a single note or handful of notes. And it gets old to listen to. By keeping the entire musical part playing you're going to move through building a well-balanced patch much quicker.

If you have a part in mind, record the MIDI with your starter/init patch, spend some time tweaking the patch while the sequence plays, and then once you get into the ballpark replay the MIDI part using your new patch. The new synth settings will influence your articulation and feel when you record the second time around. Then refine your patch as needed. Rinse and repeat until you're satisfied.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Ehhh it’s more nuanced than that. Automating the mod wheel can drastically change the timbre of an orchestral vst, and is an essential part of humanizing your program, and I think a lot of people don’t really get that. They just open up the abbey road plugin and start hammering out chords. 

A lot of those instruments don’t use velocity info to  change the timbre of the instrument, they rely on the mod wheel, while the velocity means something else (often portamemto, or note glide for the not nerds)

author: spectrummasters
content: Logic Gang: quick share, Im finding the sample delay tool v useful in a few ways and reccommend for a few reasons. Picking up on the midi ticks convo last week, if youre programming in Logic , instead of dragging (and losing track of your moves) in the timeline/piano roll....throw one of these on an insert and increase the delay in tiny increments as you run down the track (typically hats and offbeat/ghost snares first) . You can quickly create the pocket youre looking for . Also added bonus...I believe under c. 12ms most people arent hearing a glaring time shift , (i dont go above 2ms ) so the delay is handy again just putting your hats , snares, percussive elements....just a millisecond or two behind/in front of each other so all your transient sounds are not hitting the 1/4,1/8, 16th counts at precisely the same instant. I find this helps with transients. Lastly, unlink the left and right on a stereo channel and youve got an instant width tool. Best for the transient and groove use tho imo.

*Keyscape* has some fantastic sounding (and unorthodox) sampled keyboard instruments. That said I'm not particularly fond of the sound of it's LA Custom C7 grand piano. Which is a little too hi-fi for my taste.

Lately I've been very impressed by NI's/Kontakt's *The Maverick* grand piano. I believe it's a vintage Bechstein grand. The sound is robust and rich without all of the "zing" that I see in a lot of full-scale sampled grand pianos. It sounds "woody" to me. I think it would make for a very nice jazz piano.

They did a really good job of sampling every facet it and it has enough flexibility that you can dial in the really intimate Nils Frahm-style damper/pedal/mechanical noises, which I like.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Oh, just one more thing. I find it very helpful to practice making patches by trying to emulate a given instrument's expression. I'm primarily thinking about note articulation, here. Modeling these behaviors is a good way to start thinking musically with a synthesizer.

So if I'm going for a "horn" instrument I want a patch that can do attack-y stabs, but also fade into notes and have complete dynamic control. It should also have some sort of brightness feature that I can open up at will, like blowing harder into some brass.

If I'm emulating a voice there's going to be a big emphasis on legato playing and fluidity, with some very expressive pitch control for bends and vibrato. Maybe some form of subtle formant control to shade the notes like a singer would with different vowel sounds.

An organ patch is going to be a dead simple note-on/note-off volume envelope with the expression coming from the addition or subtraction of different oscillators.

And some patches are just going to be gangly chaotic messes that you do your best to wrangle. Something with a lot of chaos and feedback and squealing. You can't control it, but you just strap in.

author: Deleted User
content: I believe it’s mainly a MIDI synchronization thing. Because of the linearities of MIDI, no event will happen simultaneously. So when you sync it with your daw, 96ppq may not be enough to precisely drop drum hits close enough to right on the grid - contributing to  the slightly off feel. That ended up sounding musical and people liked that feel

1. I found when there’s a million samples I get uninterested quickly. I’d prefer 2 snare sounds as opposed to 15 slight variations of nearly the same thing.

2. I use an MPC, so the lower volume thing would be annoying for my personal use, but that’s an outlier.

author: Deleted User
content:
1) Different tunings, Having clean vs processed, peaking at below -6, good velocity layers, round robin is good but not really necessary for me, I personally don’t need all mics separate but would like to have a separate room sample and the mixed sample as well.

2) Yes please!! I hate it when samples peak at 0. I actually turn all of them down when I put them into a sampler to make it peak at -8 to -12

3) small snippets of hihats or snare ghost notes and some tom loops. I’d probably prefer them mixed only

4) for kits I think it is important. Round robin and velocity layers, and if you are doing rooms or separate mics having a kit makes an instantly playable and tweakable kit.

5) I’m not sure. Anything between 44.1/16 and 48/24 should be fine! Anything beyond might be too much

author: LAPhill
content: Another thing to keep in mind is that most libraries, especially orchestral ones, require a negative predelay for the notes to sound in time. Often somewhere between 10-50ms, but some are up to 300ms. So if everything feels late to the grid, it likely needs an offset. If it's the gentle attack of the recorded performance, not much you can do besides try a different articulation or library.

author: LAPhill
content:
There are a couple ways to think about this - do you want maximally realistic results with less control over the actual notes, or do you want to make it sound as good as possible while still maintaining compositional ownership? I pretty much always fall into the latter.

As long as you have a decent library with enough round robins, short string lines are one of the easiest things to make sound good. I haven't used BBCSO, but I know it's light on variations in exchange for having a full set of orchestral instruments and articulations at a budget price. Any of Spitfire's main libraries would be fine, or Cinematic Studio Strings, Orchestral Tools.. pretty much anything should do the job as long as it has enough round robins and hopefully at least 4 dynamic layers.

author: austenballard
content:
There are two sides to that though

I am grateful that I only ever had to splice tape in school and that I don't need a six-seven figure analog studio and the Wrecking Crew to make a track

drag-and-drop samples, vocal comping, time stretching... these are things people who came before me spent days or weeks doing. VST synthesizers! Kontakt! 

we can do more, faster, because we don't have to muddle through every little thing. but this also means we have an obligation to learn how to combine the things that have become easy into new challenges and adventures

in 50ish years we went from Sgt Pepper to Skrillex because of this

it's the drive that humans who want to achieve and accomplish and push beyond possess

author: Adam Thein
content:
I use both AD and SD.  

AD was easier for me to learn and jump into, but I'd say it's also a little more limited in how realistic you can get depending on the ADpaks you have.  Great for getting something in quickly, and I still use it quite a bit.

SD definitely had a learning curve for me but DAMN you can go deep if you really want to tweak out on drum programming.  There are tons of articulations, tons of microphones, and the expansions are all super in depth as well so you can shop around and figure out what is best.  It's definitely at a premium though for price, and I don't reach for it as often if I'm trying to get an idea out quickly, but I just used it today to play in some hihats because it sounds closer to real to my ears than AD.

The other thing I'd add about SD is the install size is pretty massive.  I have the core library with all the mics installed and their EZX kick and snares library and it's taking 250GB on one of my externals.  Oh by the way you can use any EZ Drummer libraries in SD which are more similar in depth to Addictive Drums stuff and they put out a few new libraries a year.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Totally. 

So I should clarify a little bit. These 3-4 patches aren't static sounds that I never change. Think of them more like initialized synth templates with pre-determined routings and modulation that I can start with and then diverge from. I still use other people's presets, but using these templates can save me a good 15 minutes every time that I want to build a new patch and don't want to start all the way from scratch. They come with a lot of built-in expression.

On most of these I've got a lot of the keyboard tracking already tuned so that a bright patch doesn't get too harsh as I go up in register or it doesn't get too flabby and lose definition in the low-end.

I've got one patch set up for very expressive pitch modulation. Lots of big sweeps and bends in the attack/release envelope phases. Think wonky Neptunes-type sounds or two-octave dive bombs. Stuff like that.

One patch is set for expressive filter and amplitude modulation. Wobbles, envelope modulations, and such. It's my go-to if I'm trying to play with some "brassy" dynamics.

One is a legato mono patch for very fluid vocal-like playing. A big emphasis on note articulation and variation. I think of it as a solo instrument.

The final one is (you called it) A nice poly synth. Think James Blake on a Prophet. Pretty standard stuff, but once again it's got keyboard tracking that's tuned up so that the patch feels rich across the entire range.

author: conor_i997
content: What are people’s main techniques for creating groove when programming drums. I know it depends but something I’ve heard is moving the hi hats slightly behind the grid and the snare slightly ahead. I also humanise the midi in logic to create more human like velocities and also mess with the swing. Just wondering if there’s any other ways of going about it

author: Deleted User
content:
Playing it or you can take a drum loop with groove you like and map out a groove template. Playing it is much faster and more feel, but often times it will need editing unless you have great timing. If it’s something loose then I’d definitely go ahead and move each notes because quantizing even 50% is going to change the feel. This is real nerdy but when there’s a really good moment in groove, I use logic’s event editor to look at how many ticks they are off by and snap other notes to somewhere near. For example, if I liked the feel of it being 40 ticks late then I’m gonna move everything (or some select notes that are in the same spot of the groove cycle) to somewhere nearby. Ticks are tempo relative so 50 ticks in 90bpm is different than 50 ticks in 120bpm. But it’s still in same relative timeline, but it’s going to feel different in different tempos. 

If you want it to groove like a drummer played it, best thing to do is play it in. You might end up quantizing or fixing velocity to al 127 later, but it’s going to be better than clicked in sequence if that is the style. Clicked in sequenced drums is its own groove too, you don’t want them having looseness so you quantize them all to 0 but you can still mess around with nudging them to be a bit behind or ahead of the grid.

author: spectrummasters
content: Thank you ruairi for your thoughts . V helpful and pertinent. I agree with you very much (at my own current level ) with regards to what mastering means, I agree it should feel like a sacred moment for everyone . Stepping away from the work and letting it take on its own life in the world , not continually calling it back for “what ifs and afterthoughts “ until the moment it was , is lost ...and now its not the capture and articulation of those days in the studio....but musical ponderings attached to those studio moments . MTC and MMC are likely your best bets. But MIDI is not sample accurate, so you can expect some milliseconds of drift at least, different each time you hit play. Might be fine for coming up with parts, but it’s not a great solution for a whole project.

author: spectrummasters
content: More hat and snare samples can then be used as quieter layers to start layering shuffles in other parts between the beats . The first 16th after the downbeat and a 16th before the the offbeat in beat 2 and 4 all work , but it’s then much more about velocity really . The idea is your hats and snares all start shuffling into each other , through the bar , again with the accent around the 3 . Resolving in beat 4 and back around for the next downbeat

author: Zach Hughes
content: Producer peeps, any recommendations for violin / strings vsts for demo'ing out parts? Closer to natural / organic sounds than overblown / processed / fake af sounds. I've got some Spitfire / NI options but wondering if there's something better out there

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. I'm asking if you want samples of solo string instruments or a string section.

For ensemble I've been enjoying the *NI Session Strings 2*. I've also got the *Spitfire BBC Symphony* but I'm less fond of those because they're recorded from an orchestral perspective and have a lot of room sound baked in, whereas *Session Strings 2* have a closer perspective. If you want an ensemble sound plus some major grit and close-miking I *do* like the *Bernard Hermann* orchestral library from Spitfire.

For solo strings the *NI Cremona Quartet* instruments are really, really nice. They're a pleasure to play with and sound fantastic. These have maximum presence too, so you can get some very direct sounds with them. I'm really enjoying them. The articulation and tonal options are extremely thorough.

A while back a few people recommended *Sunset Strings* by Realitone. While I haven't used it yet, they look very promising. They seem to be serving people who want a rock/pop string feel, which could be just the ticket.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Does anyone know if there's a program, synth, or protocol that allows you to modulate synthesizer envelope times based on the duration of the MIDI note?

For example, if I draw a quarter note (on the piano roll) and my synth plays a one octave downward sweep it would take a quarter note's worth of time to execute that sweep. But if I draw a MIDI note with a whole-note duration the synthesizer would modulate it's envelope time and that same sweep would descend over the course of a whole-note.

The synth would have to read upcoming MIDI note lengths from the the piano roll and modulate it's parameters on a note by note basis by reading the note duration before the note-on message. There would have to be some sort of communication between the synth and the DAW, and of course it would not work in real time.

author: Slow Hand
content: The *Massive X* sequencer is close, but you still need to trigger the sequence using a held MIDI note, so there's this extra layer of abstraction between drawing the gesture and triggering it.

author: Skyler Young

Yeah unfortunately the biggest issues with DAWs in my opinion is plugins being able to see into the future. Plugins are limited to what is happening in the current buffer.

Could be done with a melodyne type system where you record the midi into the plug-in before hand

author: Slow Hand
content: My first reaction is that Melodyne-esque pre-loading sounds like trading one crummy problem for another, but maybe there's a way to make the process happen a lot faster since it's only MIDI data, and far more lightweight.

author: Slow Hand
content:
The only way without more communication between the DAW and the plugin, right? That sounds right. Do you find yourself wishing for similar features often when designing plugins? What else would you like to see implemented, if you could have a new protocol?

Have you looked into the MIDI 2.0 protocol at all? (I haven't) I wonder if it could be expanded to poll timeline information from the DAW. It would still be a tall order to get all parties (plugin devs and DAWs) to agree on something like that, but not impossible.

author: Skyler Young
content:
Yes! Daws would have to send note length info - which would be super easy for them to add. I just think because midi is originally mostly geared at live playing they don’t do it and could cause a crazy amount of bugs if plugins don’t implement correctly

Yes - this is something that could unlock many types of new effects being made. For example my reverse note function would not have to be locked to a single note length anymore. Honestly that’s the only thing that I really have felt is strongly needed

Have not looked into midi 2.0 yet but I need to !

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. I'm excited to see what MIDI 2.0 can do, but I don't see many developers implementing it. Roland has released MIDI 2.0 keyboards, and the new line of NI keyboards seems to have it (though it may not be fully implemented).

I wonder when DAWs will start implementing it. I'm curious to know if having more CC resolution is going to make an appreciable difference in performance.

author: chris_donlin
content: Does anyone have a quick way to take a melodic riff on guitar/keys/etc and have each note play in reverse? I dont want the whole clip to just play backwards. I want the melody the same. Slice to new midi track in ableton almost gets me there but i cant reverse the samples within each sampler... or can i?

author: Slow Hand
content:
I don't think *slice to MIDI* is the way here. It will become tedious if you have rests in between notes.

Imagine that you have a quarter note followed by a quarter note rest in your melody. If you *slice to MIDI* it will slice that sequence into a half-note length clip. If you then reverse that clip the rest will play *first*, followed by the reversed quarter note.

author: Zack Hames
content:
-Pro Tools
-when i load samples they 99% of the time automatically load as loops. and it takes at least 3 clicks or more to get it to just be a normal *one shot* that is triggered.
-when I try to move the knobs for things like velocity or pitch, it gets stuck/doesn't work. I just found that if I use the scroll wheel, that seems smoother/consistent, but I hate the feeling of doing that.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I don't give a major fuck about being able to tweak the sounds other than pitch within a sampler. (don't need effects or EQ built in necessarily but it can be nice)
I do like using battery for key-tracking samples. but again, it still loads everything as a fucking loop by default. I just read the *entire* manual, there is 0 way to change the default way it loads in.

author: Zack Hames
content:
here's the workflow:

I don't use many of the preset kits anymore. Just not really the sounds I'm looking for. I have a massive library of samples that i like to use. Accessing those is easy.
The problem is I don't make preset kits. Every session, every kit, is a different combination of things, always starting fresh. So I am in the Library view constantly going through samples/files to load into any Cell of Battery.

When I find a sound I like, I can click it or drag it to the cell I want. This is all great.

But, the second i drop it in, I have to change the velocity from 0-100% (I saved my default preset to have all cells at 0% velocity which seems to be working). and then *every time i add a new sample or replace a sample* it makes it a loop in the "Editor" window. There is no shortcut, no preference, no saving a preset, that allows me to essentially remove that behavior.

author: cian riordan
content: Or maybe some midi meta data getting piped through? What are you generating your midi notes with?

author: Zack Hames
content:
I've got my prophet 6 going midi out to a MOTU midi USB interface...it doesn't matter if I use that, put a midi note in the piano roll with my mouse, or if I click the cell to hear the sound, it all behaves the same way.

I am going to experiment with the files themselves and where the files live to see if it fixes anything.

"load into cell" so far has not worked. it just sits there and nothing loads in. IDK if that's a sample rate issue of some kind

author: baccwardshead
content: Hey guys! I'm in the market for MIDI Drum Pads for finger drumming/playing drums live or during production. Torn between the Maschine Mikro Mk3, the simple Akai MPD218 and splurging for the Push 2/3 or bigger Maschine. Analysis paralysis :/

author: BatMeckley
content: The machine series kinda locks you into the machine architecture and software. You can KINDA use it as regular midi pads but it’s very very limited outside maschine. The mpd 218 you can setup to work with any software.

author: Slow Hand
content: What do you mean it feels like hitting cardboard? Does the instrument have bad velocity mapping that feels unnatural? Or does it have poor response time when you use your electronic kit?

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Yeah you're on the money, the cardboard feel is a mix of velocity mapping and the dynamic response of the samples, feels unnatural and unresponsive.

Stuff like Toontrack & Addictive feel great on the kit (ie more natural dynamic response, more layers and nuance), but aren't as mix-ready.

GGD say that with M&M2 they explicitly addressed this

author: Slow Hand
content: Glad to hear they're addressing it. You may be able to finesse the dynamics by adjusting the MIDI velocity curve going to the instrument. Something like this.

author: Slow Hand
content: I imagine most electronic kits will have this feature that lets you bend the transfer curve, but you could always use a device to filter the MIDI messages before they reach the plugin. A lot of DAWs have them these days.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Good shout, appreciate the thoughts!

The libraries have velocity curves per kit item built in, been mucking about with it but there's a mix of not enough velocity layers (which get even more uneven spread when changing velocity curves), few round robins, not enough variety in the samples, and just something else with the response I can't put my finger on. 

I starting to think there might be an inverse correlation between basic mix-readiness/consistency and play feel. 

Curious where M&M2 falls, but a bit daunted with the opportunity cost of familiarizing myself with another full-featured sampler/mixer 😅

author: Ross Fortune
content: Beyond the velocity layers etc, are there any steps you could try like easing off / bypassing onboard bus / individual compression?

author: Rob Domos
content: Maybe you take it for granted but as a shitty producer myself who has rarely touched a mod wheel on a production and usually clicked/drew in everything that wasn’t just the velocity information this was sick to me

author: Rollmottle
content: Yup. I wasn’t trying to equate performing and mixing or even specifically talking about making orchestral VSTs go. Just reacting to the idea that turning off the performance (or mix or songwriting or some other inextricably linked piece of music)  is some major revelation…see how much better it is when it’s performed!? See how much better it is when you work on it!? Well…yeah.
